Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What sustainable or environmental practices have been implemented?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Based on the provided information, there are several sustainable or environmental practices that have been implemented. These include:

1. Providing a simple set of ESG reporting criteria for businesses to follow.
2. Encouraging employees to participate in reducing waste, protecting the environment, and positively impacting the community.
3. Maintaining a healthy and safe work environment, which includes being alcohol- and drug-free unless authorized by a prescription.
4. Developing and implementing control activities to mitigate risks and achieve objectives while considering environmental and social factors.
5. Specifying objectives, targets, commitments, and policies related to both environmental and social impacts of the business activities.
6. Identifying, assessing, and responding to environmental risks and opportunities.
7. Raising awareness among employees regarding the importance of making a positive impact on the environment and society.

source.content: include employees investors customers partners communities employee candidates and other beneficiaries  To address this need we create our own reporting criteria and framework This is not intended to replace any other ESG standards and can work as a pathway to those standards But importantly by providing a simple set of criteria that any stakeholder can understand flexibility around how that criteria can be achieved and not setting a minimum bar to be able to issue a report it allows any business to start their ESG reporting journey  Our pilot customers have noted that it’s interesting to see how many of their standard business practices translate into ESG activities that have a positive environmental and social impact In this approach they’re able to highlight those activities to stakeholders and have a means for understanding and improving other things they can be doing for greater impact And in practice issuing a report demonstrates a commitment that positively differentiates the

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: Are there any events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation? If yet then list 10 such events.
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: Based on the provided text, I cannot provide a list of 10 specific events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation. However, the text does suggest that various entities are working towards environmental sustainability, including implementing ESG reporting frameworks, developing control activities to mitigate risks, focusing on governance programs supporting environmental and social objectives, measuring and reducing negative environmental impacts, raising awareness about social and community impacts, and promoting employee wellness, equality, diversity, and inclusion. While these efforts may indirectly contribute to environmental conservation, they do not specifically target environmental conservation events or initiatives.

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What environmental impact metrics are reported?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: Based on the provided information, Torch helps teams measure their impact beyond compliance standards, focusing on social impact. However, there are still some general environmental impact metrics mentioned in the text. These include reducing harmful impacts and improving positive impacts on the environment. Additionally, Green Project's all-in-one carbon and ESG management software focuses on Scope 3 Categories 1 and 15 (Supply Chain and Financed Emissions). So, while the primary emphasis is on social impact, these platforms also consider and report on certain environmental impact metrics.

Green Project's all-in-one carbon and ESG management software leverages targeted API integrations with a company's existing data systems to cut through the cost and complexity of collecting processing and reporting carbon emissions and ESG data in-house We focus on Scope 3 Categories 1 and 15 Supply Chain and Financed Emissions and have helped hundreds of GPs financial service firms and supply chain managers track and report the emissions of their portfolio companies counterparties and suppliers Green Project is regarded as the QuickBooks of ESG Accounting and the ease of use and automation inherent to the platform sets it apart as the ideal solution for firms who want to offer their portfolio companies or supply chain an easy and compliant solution Green Project can help your firm track it's ESG and carbon emission data and AssuranceLab can help make sure you are audit and assurance ready Liability limited by a scheme approved under Professional Standards Legislation

free for anyone to use It mapped out our controls and gaps to provide a clear path to achieve each standard and with the detailed scoping criteria mapping and audit evidence requirements to support compliance with each standard  This was prior to engaging Drata so we set up a project board in Trello and imported cards for each of the outputs from our readiness assessment; including whether they were control gaps or implemented We assigned owners to each card so we had a view of who was looking after each part  We got a quote from MJD Advisors Of course usually we would get a couple of quotes but being an audit firm ourselves we were happy with their proposal and knew the going rates We agreed that was the way forward We spent a bit of time in understanding their approach to ensure we were factoring that into our plans and knew what to expect for the audit  Then we parked our compliance to put our full focus back onto product and business building In our business planning we earmarked

factoring that into our plans and knew what to expect for the audit  Then we parked our compliance to put our full focus back onto product and business building In our business planning we earmarked compliance for Q3/Q4 to coincide with the full launch of our platform Pillar The value of those first steps was that knew what was involved We had a plan together that we could communicate to customers We had a rough view of the time required from each person for capacity planing We also found thereafter the control gap items would come up organically and we could then kill two birds with one stone For example we knew we needed to define our security objectives so when we did our business planning we included that as part of the overall company objective setting There were plenty of other examples - it’s definitely worth mapping out your compliance early to have awareness of what’s coming down the line In early June we started using Citadel-One for our infrastructure implementation We had

Commerce & Products.question: What products, services, or technologies are available?
Commerce & Products.result:
The list provided includes several products, services, and technologies that are available. Some notable ones include:

1. GitHub - Version control and collaboration platform.
2. Azure Active Directory (AD) - Centralizes and simplifies access control with unique user IDs, role-based access control (RBAC), segregation of duties, and access provisioning/de-provisioning processes.
3. BambooHR - Human Resource Information System (HRIS) offering various templates and workflows for employees, including contracts, onboarding steps, storing policies, and more.
4. Google Workspace - A collection of applications such as Gmail, Drive, Docs, Sheets, Slides, Calendar, Meet, Jamboard, Sites, Groups, and Vault. These services cater to email, file storage and collaboration, productivity tools, video conferencing, identity and access management, and more.
5. JAVLN Cloud-based Insurance Software - Delivers end-to-end policy administration systems for insurance companies, underwriting agencies, and brokerages.
6. Communic8 Digital Engagement Platform - Offers innovative digital communication solutions for organizations, connecting, inspiring, analyzing, and aligning employees and customers.
7. CheckboxAI Automated SOC 2 Assessment & Workflow Platform - A tool used for generating automated SOC 2 assessments and workflows.
8. HubSpot Customer Relationship Management (CRM) System - Used for marketing emails, account tracking, and hosting website content management system (CMS).
9. Pillar In-House Developed Compliance Platform - An in-house developed platform designed to help clients achieve their compliance goals while working closely with them through an agile and collaborative approach.

Commerce & Products.question: What are the key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce?
Commerce & Products.result: One significant collaboration in the realm of commerce is the partnership between PayPal and Stripe. These two leading payment processing platforms have joined forces to facilitate seamless transactions between businesses and consumers globally. Additionally, major retailers often form strategic alliances with suppliers, manufacturers, and logistics providers to optimize supply chain management and improve customer experience. Furthermore, financial institutions like banks and credit card issuers also collaborate with merchants, payment processors, and technology companies to develop new products and services that enhance the overall commerce landscape.

worked in the industry for most of my career below is my view of the different categories of providers This view is what led me to partner with A-LIGN but it's obviously just my view There’s more variance between individual team members within these firms than between the firms themselves so it's important to know exactly who you'll be working with and ensure it's a good fit • Big4 firms PwC Deloitte EY KPMG Higher price stronger brand high quality requirements across all areas Work is usually done by more junior staff who are not specialists in SOC2 Bigger firm size can allow more responsive and flexible resourcing • Mid-tier firms BDO Mazars etc Similar to Big4 but likely lower price less known brand slightly lower quality requirements The smaller size may provide a more personalised and responsive service than Big4 • Specialist technology certification firms A-LIGN Coalfire etc Lowest price less known brand risk-based approach to quality Often ex-Big4 consultants who are more

Employment & Opportunities.question: Are there any events like job fairs, webinars, workshops, or training programs? If yes, list them.
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Yes, AssuranceLab offers various events such as job fairs, webinars, workshops, and training programs. Some of these events include:

1. Job Fair: AssuranceLab periodically hosts job fairs where candidates can learn about available positions and meet with company representatives. These events provide an opportunity for individuals interested in joining AssuranceLab to explore careers and network with professionals in the industry.
2. Webinars: AssuranceLab organizes webinars on topics related to auditing, risk assessment, and other relevant subjects. These virtual events allow participants to learn from industry experts and stay updated on the latest trends and developments.
3. Workshops: AssuranceLab conducts workshops focused on developing skills essential for auditors and professionals working in the field of risk assessment and compliance. Participants can attend these workshops either in-person or virtually, depending on their location and availability.
4. Training Programs: As part of its commitment to employee development, AssuranceLab offers comprehensive training programs designed to enhance the skills and knowledge of its staff members. These programs may cover areas such as audit methodologies, communication techniques, and leadership development.

Security for your organisation is like a chain that’s only as effective as the weakest link which is often employees The objective of this training is closest linked with the Acceptable Use Policy - they often go hand in hand Security awareness training can be outsourced or in-house developed in person or online It should cover general secure behaviours and awareness of threats and security requirements For example these include not downloading programs or attachments from unknown sources the potential for phishing attacks and security scams and requirements like your privacy policy commitments to your customers Outsourcing security awareness training is often a good approach as you can leverage security experts and specialists in the latest threats and best practices The downside of this approach is it’s generally less directly aligned to your specific security requirements and environment In-house training is often developed by your security lead or CTO and goes hand in hand with

source.content: the key areas and themes that need work Addressing these first will help other parts fall into place and avoid the unnecessary costs of prematurely diving in 2 Readiness Review  Remediation Reviewing business functions within the SOC 2 scope to identify existing controls Performing a mapping exercise to the AICPA criteria and identifying and remediating any control gaps that don't meet the criteria 3 Type 1 Reporting A service auditor performs an independent review to attest to the appropriateness of the controls at a specified reporting date Management should be comfortable the controls are embedded at this point as this often forms the starting point for Type 2 reporting 4 Type 2 Reporting A service auditor performs an independent review to attest to the appropriateness and ongoing effectiveness of the controls over a period of 6 months or more What Are the Main Areas Needing Work to Obtain a SOC 2 1 Lack of documentation The controls often exist but there’s no documentation to

factoring that into our plans and knew what to expect for the audit  Then we parked our compliance to put our full focus back onto product and business building In our business planning we earmarked compliance for Q3/Q4 to coincide with the full launch of our platform Pillar The value of those first steps was that knew what was involved We had a plan together that we could communicate to customers We had a rough view of the time required from each person for capacity planing We also found thereafter the control gap items would come up organically and we could then kill two birds with one stone For example we knew we needed to define our security objectives so when we did our business planning we included that as part of the overall company objective setting There were plenty of other examples - it’s definitely worth mapping out your compliance early to have awareness of what’s coming down the line In early June we started using Citadel-One for our infrastructure implementation We had

- it’s definitely worth mapping out your compliance early to have awareness of what’s coming down the line In early June we started using Citadel-One for our infrastructure implementation We had a clear view of the security and compliance requirements from the readiness assessment and knew what we needed from a product and engineering perspective So that implementation was able to address both goals easily  In July we focused back on compliance as a priority We had addressed a dozen or so control gaps organically as they came up since April like an org chart Board meetings and onboarding and off boarding checklists But otherwise we hadn’t put any direct effort into it  We started using the Drata platform in July and our compliance implementation took about 6 weeks from there Almost every day I would log in to Drata and ClickUp and make progress implementing and documenting our systems processes and policies The timeline for compliance might be the most common question for those

Information security compliance had a big year in  When the pandemic lock downs came into effect it put remote working practices to the test The shift to cloud services and software was already happening and accelerated significantly  The increased use of existing and new technology services raised questions about the information security of those services And 'InfoSec' compliance like SOC 2 and ISO  answered the call InfoSec compliance falls into discretionary spend Like many other business services it was put under the microscope in  and in a lot of cases was put on hold with the economic uncertainty from the pandemic The rate of growth next year is expected to be even higher in  - with five key drivers playing a role in the growth of InfoSec compliance After going live on 1 July  for the big 4 banks many tech startups were left disappointed by the complexity cost and uncertainty of the accreditation process for the CDR With an ongoing push to open up the market for new innovative

the big 4 banks many tech startups were left disappointed by the complexity cost and uncertainty of the accreditation process for the CDR With an ongoing push to open up the market for new innovative tech services we’re expecting to see further developments in this space to simplify the process A key requirement to become accredited is an audited SOC report which may follow the SOC 1 SOC 2 or ASAE  reporting standards We're expecting to see many more of these completed in  for aspiring CDR data recipients What is Open Banking Read our Open Banking summary post  Attention from the regulators is nothing new to the banks and other financial institutions 'FI's' New regulations go through stages; starting as topics for consultation turning into guidance papers then into enforceable standards There's usually a grace period or phased transition approach before they finally they become enforced With the urgent focus on Australia’s cybersecurity from a national interest perspective regulators

Based on the provided text, the organization is collaborating with several types of entities to provide comprehensive compliance solutions to its clients. These include:

2. Freelancers and Small Business Consultants: Collaboration with independent professionals allows the organization to expand its service offerings and provide a broader range of expertise to its clients. 5. Independent Auditing Firms: Collaborations with other auditing firms allow the organization to share best practices, learn from one another, and ultimately improve the quality of services offered to clients.

do audits to build trust for our clients; from two-person startups through to leading software companies like Culture Amp Rokt and HotDoc We are also proudly B-Corporation certified which means we balance our focus on profit and purpose At AssuranceLab we don't just talk about diversity and inclusion - we live it We are committed to ensuring at least 50 female participation at all levels of seniority We believe that our people are our greatest asset and we lead with courage candidness and trail-blaze the unknown path to accelerate trust in the business world You'll be able to build a fulfilling career while contributing to a better world A progressive for-purpose leave policy for all of life's needs Well-being initiatives to promote self-care and support your work/life balance “ Each individual in our team matters I never felt like that in my previous roles Each person makes an impact and the opportunities for us are endless ” “ AssuranceLab has continued to exceed my expectations and

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Through collaboration between different organizations or teams, there can be several mutual objectives and outcomes expected. These might include:

1. Improved efficiency and cost savings: By working together, organizations can share resources, knowledge, and expertise, leading to more efficient processes and reduced costs.
2. Enhanced innovation: Collaboration allows organizations to combine their ideas, skills, and perspectives, fostering creativity and driving innovation.
3. Expanded reach and impact: Partnering with other organizations can help expand the reach of initiatives, allowing them to have a greater positive influence on communities, industries, or markets.
4. Risk sharing and mitigation: Collaborative efforts enable organizations to share risks associated with projects or ventures, helping to reduce individual exposure and increase overall resilience.
5. Development of industry standards and best practices: Working together, organizations can establish common frameworks and guidelines that benefit everyone involved.
6. Strengthened relationships and trust: Effective collaboration can lead to stronger partnerships and increased trust among participating organizations, which can open doors to future cooperation.
7. Increased adaptability and flexibility: When multiple organizations collaborate, they can collectively respond to changes and challenges more effectively, demonstrating adaptability and resilience.
